Award.AwardTitle: I-Corps: The Commercialization Potential of Pyrazolate Metal-Organic Frameworks (MOFs)
Award.AbstractNarration:
Metal-organic frameworks (MOF) are a class of materials built of inorganic clusters and rigid organic linkers to form open, three-dimensional frameworks that possess unique pore geometries and functionalities for novel material engineering. The use of MOFs provides safe alternatives for electrolytes, mitigate electrolyte degradation, and enable the use of high-energy electrode materials, such as sulfur, metal fluorides, and lithium that are traditionally limited by reaction with liquid electrolytes. They also enable the separation of alkane isomers by shape, which can be applied to gasoline upgrading, and enhance the margins of oil refineries by enabling them to either sell high octane gasoline for a premium or mix it into cheaper gasoline to reduce production costs. This I-Corps team has developed a class of conductive Metal-Organic Frameworks (MOFs), three-dimensional structures built of inorganic clusters and rigid organic linkers that display high ionic conductivities and electron mobility, as well as extraordinary selectivity for separation of alkane isomers. These properties make them suitable for applications in batteries and gasoline upgrading.

Compared to traditional porous materials such as zeolites and activated carbons, MOFs have the wide diversity of pore structures and chemical properties that can be obtained by the judicious selection of metal ions and ligands. They can be further tailored by post-synthetic treatments to maximize conductivity or selectivity for separations. Upon chemical reduction, the electron mobility of the conductive MOFs becomes comparable to amorphous silicon and organic conductive polymers. By altering the ligand to access ligand-based redox couples, the capacity of MOFs could be drastically increased to values greater than materials used in lithium ion batteries. Thus, chemical modification can be used to enhance the conductivities of MOFs so that they can be applied to specific battery applications. At the same time, in contrast with the obtuse pore angles of zeolites, Fe2(BDP)3, a pyrazolate MOF has acutely angled pores. This enables the selection of molecules based on their shape, which provide varied adsorption enthalpies for linear, di and mono-branched alkane isomers for separation. As a result, separations currently carried out inefficiently, such as separating di-branched hexane isomers from mono-branched and linear isomers, could be performed with a substantially increased efficiency.

Institution.Name: University of California-Berkeley
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF CALIFORNIA, THE

POR.DRECONTENT:
Metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) are a well-known class of three-dimensional, porous materials composed of metal ions bridged by organic linkers. Through judicious selection of the linker and metal, a wide range of structures are accessible, with varying pore geometries and environments. Metal-organic frameworks also exhibit extremely large surface areas, and as little as one cubic centimeter of some materials can have the same internal surface area as an entire football field. Their high tunability and large surface areas have rendered MOFs of great interest in many applications ranging from medicine to industry, while the most promising area continues to be in gas separations relevant to industry and clean energy. The goal of this UC Berkeley-based I-Corps project was to determine the best strategies for transitioning MOFs from the lab to development and commercialization through a startup company. The team consisted of principle investigator Professor Jeffrey R. Long, who has nearly two decades of experience in MOF chemistry and serves as Deputy Director of the Center for Gas Separations Relevant to Clean Energy Technologies; Dr. Xiaoding Zhuo, an entrepreneurial lead with two years of cleantech investment experience and business development and strategy experience in the energy industry; and project mentor Dr. Steven Kaye, currently a Manager in Advanced Materials at Apple and former Chief Scientific Officer at Wildcat Technology Discoveries. The team carried out extensive customer interviews and market analysis to identify value applications for MOFs and to develop go-to-market strategies in the broad regime of gas separations.


Over the course of the project, the team travelled to conferences and customer sites to perform interviews, engage interest in the MOF technology, and negotiate potential partnerships and co-development deals. Interviews were conducted to fully understand customer needs, and business strategies were developed based on the use of MOFs to meet these needs. Contacts were selected based on hypothesis-driven criteria and those markets with the greatest potential to invest in and benefit from MOF technology, including oil and gas companies and California-based biogas facilities. Some travel was made to collect in-person interviews, such as to the 2015 ARPA-E Summit at Washington DC and Energy Week at UT Austin at Texas. The project also encompassed materials development, with a focus on determining optimal synthesis and scale up of promising MOFs and screening for binders and techniques to make shaped particles suitable for industrial separations.

Gratifyingly, the team acquired essential knowledge to form a successful startup, and the team concluded on a GO decision with a focus on developing diamine-appended MOFs that exhibit a remarkable ability to separate carbon dioxide from industrially-relevant gas mixtures. The startup company Mosaic Materials, Inc. was correspondingly founded in 2014 by Jeffrey Long, Steven Kaye, and Dr. Thomas McDonald, who received his PhD in the Long group and discovered the diamine-appended MOFs. Current efforts are focused on the scale-up and pelletization of these materials, and the company has received various seed funding, for example from the California Energy Commission for the use of these materials in the purification of biogas. Looking ahead, the successful development and implementation of these materials on an industrial scale promises to substantially reduce the capital and energy costs currently associated with carbon capture and to reduce anthropogenic carbon dioxide by as much as an enormous 50% worldwide.


Last Modified: 06/02/2016
Modified by: Jeffrey R Long
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: Metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) are a well-known class of three-dimensional, porous materials composed of metal ions bridged by organic linkers. Through judicious selection of the linker and metal, a wide range of structures are accessible, with varying pore geometries and environments. Metal-organic frameworks also exhibit extremely large surface areas, and as little as one cubic centimeter of some materials can have the same internal surface area as an entire football field. Their high tunability and large surface areas have rendered MOFs of great interest in many applications ranging from medicine to industry, while the most promising area continues to be in gas separations relevant to industry and clean energy. The goal of this UC Berkeley-based I-Corps project was to determine the best strategies for transitioning MOFs from the lab to development and commercialization through a startup company. Long, who has nearly two decades of experience in MOF chemistry and serves as Deputy Director of the Center for Gas Separations Relevant to Clean Energy Technologies; Dr. Xiaoding Zhuo, an entrepreneurial lead with two years of cleantech investment experience and business development and strategy experience in the energy industry; and project mentor Dr. Steven Kaye, currently a Manager in Advanced Materials at Apple and former Chief Scientific Officer at Wildcat Technology Discoveries. The team carried out extensive customer interviews and market analysis to identify value applications for MOFs and to develop go-to-market strategies in the broad regime of gas separations. Over the course of the project, the team travelled to conferences and customer sites to perform interviews, engage interest in the MOF technology, and negotiate potential partnerships and co-development deals. Interviews were conducted to fully understand customer needs, and business strategies were developed based on the use of MOFs to meet these needs. Some travel was made to collect in-person interviews, such as to the 2015 ARPA-E Summit at Washington DC and Energy Week at UT Austin at Texas. The project also encompassed materials development, with a focus on determining optimal synthesis and scale up of promising MOFs and screening for binders and techniques to make shaped particles suitable for industrial separations. The startup company Mosaic Materials, Inc. was correspondingly founded in 2014 by Jeffrey Long, Steven Kaye, and Dr. Thomas McDonald, who received his PhD in the Long group and discovered the diamine-appended MOFs. Current efforts are focused on the scale-up and pelletization of these materials, and the company has received various seed funding, for example from the California Energy Commission for the use of these materials in the purification of biogas. Looking ahead, the successful development and implementation of these materials on an industrial scale promises to substantially reduce the capital and energy costs currently associated with carbon capture and to reduce anthropogenic carbon dioxide by as much as an enormous 50% worldwide.
